dublin_core.dcvalue: PURPOSE A telehealth based chronic disease management program including clinical pharmacy specialists CPSs and the program s impact on primary care outcomes in a population of veterans are described SUMMARY A telehealth program including CPS services was developed to improve healthcare access and quality for veterans in rural areas of the Pacific Northwest Outcomes of medication management services provided by a CPS team during both clinical video telehealth and telephone encounters with 554 patients from October 2014 to March 2017 were assessed Patients were targeted for diabetes DM hyperlipidemia HLD and hypertension HTN control and tobacco cessation the respective primary outcomes were the mean changes from baseline in glycosylated hemoglobin HbA1c and blood pressure values and rates of guideline indicated statin therapy and tobacco cessation Patients in the DM and HTN groups had a mean absolute HbA1c reduction of 1 61 95 confidence interval CI 1 39 1 83 p Under 0 0001 and a mean systolic blood pressure reduction of 26 00 mm Hg 95 CI 22 99 28 50 mm Hg p Under 0 001 respectively In the HLD group 93 of patients were discharged on a lipid lowering medication Tobacco cessation was achieved in 42 of targeted patients CONCLUSION CPSs providing primary care comprehensive medication management services solely via telehealth improved disease management and access to healthcare in a population of rural veterans Statistically significant improvements in DM and HTN outcomes were demonstrated along with clinically significant improvements in the areas of lipid management and tobacco cessation
Made available in DSpace on 2020-06-08T14:14:51Z (GMT). No. of bitstreams: 0 Previous issue date: 2-11-30
American journal of health-system pharmacy : AJHP : official journal of the American Society of Health-System Pharmacists
Impact of the clinical pharmacy specialist in telehealth primary care.
